node.title: ‘Prayers for the Stolen’ Review: Coming of Age Among the Poppies
node.alt: Marya Membreño, center, as one of the girls who give up their long hair in order to deflect attention from predatory cartel members, in “Prayers for the Stolen,” directed by Tatiana Huezo.
node.description: Tatiana Huezo’s feature film is based on a novel about girls growing up in Mexico in communities terrorized by opium cartels.
node.content: ["In \u201cPrayers for the Stolen,\u201d the first narrative feature by the Mexican-Salvadoran documentarian Tatiana Huezo, young 8-year-old girls weep as their mothers chop off their long tresses under the pretext of preventing head lice. In reality, their boyish haircuts are meant to disguise their true genders from the cartel members who terrorize their rural Mexican town.", "Soon the girls will grow hardened to the reality that plagues the sparkling and verdant highlands surrounding their remote village. These criminals kidnap, sexually assault and often leave for dead any girls they can get their hands on.", "Loosely based on Jennifer Clement\u2019s 2014 novel of the same name, \u201cPrayers for the Stolen\u201d is on the one hand a meandering coming-of-age film, sensitively charting the evolution of Ana and her two girlfriends, Paula and Maria. The girls covertly apply makeup behind their mothers\u2019 backs, fantasize about their schoolteachers and eventually embark on small flirtations of their own. But violence circumscribes their every whim.", "The threat posed by the cartel, which runs a poppy harvesting operation using the townspeople\u2019s cheap labor, undermines any sense of normality. Black SUVs can come charging from across the valley without warning, forcing the girls into hiding, and helicopters spraying toxic pesticides to preserve the opium-producing crop often invade during playtime.", "A leap forward in time turns the girls into young women. A new set of older actresses steps in to play the girls at 13, and their masculine hairdos aren\u2019t fooling anyone.", "The film swings back and forth from scenes of pastoral bliss to brutality, generating a narrative that, while unfocused, is nevertheless anchored by the tender and wounded performances by its adolescent cast.", "In the end, tragedy arrives abruptly, an unsurprising turn given the unchanging circumstances, yet one that imparts a girl with a sudden awakening to the monumental bleakness of her fate."]
